item.title: XML parsing in PHP - Pixelcode
item.description:
XML parsing in PHP - Pixelcode

We firstly need to create the parser: $parser = xml_parser_create(); When the parser reads the XML it can call functions that we can then add code to handle. The code below makes the parser call function when a new element is found within an XML document, and when the end of an element is detected.

I'm in the middle of upgrading old servers but it was just only yesterday that I found Ubuntu 12.04 didn't install the MIB files. Even if you install the SNMP applications. It was really strange to launch tkmib and just see a couple of nodes. The explanation is simple.

item.title: Apache Server Guide Archives - Make Tech Easier
item.description:
Apache Server Guide Archives - Make Tech Easier

Apache web server is the most popular web server around the world. As a continuation of part 1, here we share advanced security tips & tricks for securing Apache web server.

item.title: RAID 0, RAID 1, RAID 5, RAID 10 Explained with Diagrams
item.description:
RAID 0, RAID 1, RAID 5, RAID 10 Explained with Diagrams

RAID stands for Redundant Array of Inexpensive (Independent) Disks. On most situations you will be using one of the following four levels of RAIDs. This article explains the main difference between these raid levels along with an easy to understand diagram.

item.title: 15 Useful MySQL/MariaDB Performance Tuning and Optimization Tips
item.description:
15 Useful MySQL/MariaDB Performance Tuning and Optimization Tips

Choosing the right filesystem is vital for your databases. Most important things you need to consider here are - data integrity, performance and ease of administration. As per MariaDB's recommendations, the best file systems are XFS, Ext4 and Btrfs. All of them are enterprise journaling filesystems that can be used with very large files and large storage volumes.

item.title: Curl: POST an XML file via cURL and PHP
item.description:
Curl: POST an XML file via cURL and PHP

curl_setopt($ch, CURLOPT_VERBOSE, 1); // set url to post to curl_setopt($ch, CURLOPT_URL, $url); // set url to post to curl_setopt($ch, CURLOPT_RETURNTRANSFER, 1); // return into a variable curl_setopt($ch, CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER, Array("Content-Type: text/xml")); curl_setopt($ch, CURLOPT_HEADER, 1); curl_setopt($ch, CURLOPT_TIMEOUT, 40); // times out after 4s curl_setopt($ch, CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS, $XPost); // add POST fields curl_setopt($ch, CURLOPT_POST, 1);

item.title: How To Set Up a Firewall Using Iptables on Ubuntu 14.04 | DigitalOcean
item.description:
How To Set Up a Firewall Using Iptables on Ubuntu 14.04 | DigitalOcean

Setting up a good firewall is an essential step to take in securing any modern operating system. Most Linux distributions ship with a few different firewall tools that we can use to configure our firewalls. In this guide, we'll be covering the iptables firewall.
